comments.commentBody: I agree that Rachel Maddow is doing phenomenal coverage of the Russia Trump ties and it is fascinating.

I'm just reminded of people like Lance Armstrong, who adamantly denied any wrongdoing for years. Only when the evidence was overwhelming and undeniable he finally admitted to some allegations.  Trump however is a different cat, no matter what truths are revealed or what happens he will never ever admit any wrongdoing or culpability.  And because of that many of his core supporters will believe he was maligned and scapegoated.  Very Sad.
Because the cyber attack helped them win the  election?

Among the flimsy, baseless articles written by the NYT for political vengeance, this is the most lacking in any coherence.

What claptrap.
Why?

???

Both parties?

Ban?

Both, Treason?

Too much coffee this morning?!

If Trump would just release his tax returns, I think the furor would die down. Or not!
As far as posting pictures of Nancy Pelosi or any other top american official meeting with Russians, well--I thought the time for trivial arguments was over! The people whose pictures he tweeted had every right to be openly meeting with such people as they were either legitimacy elected or appointed. Candidate Trump and his team having so many contacts with a hostile foreign power who hacked our elections naturally raises suspicion...esp since Trump has tried to keep it secret, has seemingly lied about it and has a history of making weirdly flattering remarks about Putin and Russian government. There's no trivial witch hunt going on here...but there should be a manhunt.

Instead of making the real story about the cheating at the New York Times, CNN, The DNC and Mr. Podesta, the media circles their wagons and decries Russian Boggyemen.  Pathetic.  This is why the media's approval rating is even below congress'.
No way those should be compromised.

The democrats lost the election, get over it! These fake conspiracy theorys are nothing more than poor loser excuses so they can drag their feet instead of working for the American people. Trump did not sell Russia 20% of our uranium, Clinton did. Trump did not give Iran billions in cash, Obama did!

Wrong on both counts fact check yourself . Clinton do not give uranium to the Russians. Obama did not give billions of cash to the Iranians. That was their money that was frozen from the sanctions and embargos against them oh by the way that cash was for money that partially was paid for weapons systems purchase from the US approved by Reagan. Of that there wer F14 Tomcats as well as other weapons. If this conspiracys were false why did they no come forward with the fact that they had meetings with the Russians. Why will Trump not release his tax returns. There is obviously something to hide here. Where there is smoke there is fire. Oh by the I have had a Security clearance as part of the experience of doing so you must always report if ever you have had contact with officials or agents of a foreign country it is very specific on that. So again why try to hide it.
No she did not. That is provably a "fake conspiracy".  If she was elected and had these meetings you'd be crying bloody murder.
Well, at the very least, all this criticism will paralyzed any attempt to make any type of concession to the Russian.

There is no harm in building relations with Russia as long as they are transparent. This will help solve many international conflicts and control terrorism in the world. Russian can be a very useful partner if properly worked with for security in Europe and well being of humanity all over the world.
No one disagrees - but Russia successfully distabilised us in 2016.
This all seems like a bad spy novel and little too mobbish for my taste.  Maybe it's just the way things are done these days--a game of thrones.

I agree completely. Ezra Klein interviews Elizabeth Drew in a recent podcast in which she expresses much the same assessment of Trump and suggests that he may not even complete his term due to his temperamental shortcomings for "the job". I believe his autocratic streak will eventually result in a major blunder.

I think there is something to the Russian connections; to my knowledge Manafort is more involved in Ukrainian politics than US politics when he is tapped to replace Trump's campaign manager (Lewandowski) after he causes embarrassment by pushing around the press at a campaign rally. And then Trump begins the "wikileaks" mantra which carries all the way through to election day.

Let's hope the Democrats get their act together by the mid-terms so that they can present some candidates that are attractive to the electorate which I believe will be less complacent than at the presidential election.
I'm guessing you mean Trump's impeachment can't come soon enough? The Dems invited the russian ambassador to the inauguration. What's going on here anyway?
Don't forget Hillary sold 20% of the US Uranium supply to Putin. How's that for companionship?

The U.S. meddles in foreign politics all the time, e.g., Ukraine, Libya, Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan, most of Central and South America, etc.  Two wrongs don't make a right, but at least we could drop the feigned outrage and blatant hypocrisy.  Even better, now that we have a taste of our own medicine, we could stop interfering in other countries' domestic affairs and let them determine their own futures.

So you're okay with Russia trashing Ukraine's autonomy and desire to join the EU, annex Crimea, commit war crimes in Syria, invade Afghanistan, and meddle in Lybia and Iraq? How much is that for letting people determine their own futures? Why was Obama blamed for NOT interfering more in Syria then?

Do you honestly believe that America could or would stop meddling in the affairs of other countries? It is in the marrow of our bones. We have been meddling almost as long as we've been a nation. The worse part of our meddling is that we aren't interested in spreading democracy across the planet - we're meddling to make countries better suited for our business interests.
That said, I agree we should stop acting like we're innocents in the world.
Fair enough - but has a foreign country ever affected OUR elections before?

Dear Amy, what a beautiful letter. It made me think about a love I'd lost.  I lost my sons father to cancer. We weren't together when he died we had separated . I found out from his then girlfriend 18 months later. I was heart broken for my son and even for me. I'd had dreams we would live in England together and watch our son play in rock pools on summer holidays in Greek islands. Suffice to say life wasn't that kind. But there are some days I believe he is there all around us in the air, making sure we are ok. I think life goes on in a different way and your love will resonate in the natural order of things. I watched my mother die of cancer and I was with her as she died. I believed she went somewhere else, another plane maybe? As she left there was a sharp knock on the window. It was 4am. Not the time for birds. Anyway I just felt compelled to write this to you. You are brave and obviously loved. Go well Amy. XxAmanda

While I now live in Vermont, I was a resident of Wisconsin from 2004-15, thus during 6 "Walker years". Please be assured that when he says "state's rights" (as loaded as that phrase is) he means "contributor's rights" Why would the Koch brothers, not residents of Wisconsin, have any influence over Wisconsin's government, and arguably more than the protestors? When he says "taking on public sector unions", he means "unions that did not support me or contribute to my campaign"--the police and firefighters unions were specifically exempted from the war on unions because they did those things. When he touts the economics of Wisconsin, look it up--last in the Midwest for job creation (yes, more are working, but that is true because you took office at the height of the Republican-caused Great Recession, NOT your governance).Yes, taxes are down--my income taxes to Wisconsin dropped 0.09% of my income, or 1.7%--but he has significantly raised the cost of government services, including tuition at the flagship university in Madison (up at least 25% in his tenure). I suspect, in total, the citizenry pays more for less.
Scott, the Articles of Confederation, with a weak Federal government, were tried and lasted 6 years before being judged a failure. The current Constitution is 229 years old. Perhaps one of the courses you didn't take while not graduating from Marquette was U.S. History?
And of course, we know what that governor did to the University of Wisconsin.

As a former Minnesotan, I must point out to the Governor how much better the economy and the people of Minnesota are doing as compared to those in Wisconsin, because they took the exact opposite tack as that advocated by Walker. Not to mention the deep damage to democratic and civil society Walker wrought on the state throughly his deeply divisive. So, go back into your hole, you lying troll.

R's love talking about what the founders would have wanted.  But there was a spectrum of thought to how much control should be given to the Feds vs the states, mainly having to do with slavery.  Regardless, what Gov Walker doesn't get is that the whole country is our community, not just his state.  Standing strong to repeal the ACA will likely destroy the R's in the midterms - so yes, please R's stand strong and do your worst. As Sen Franken says, we all do well when we all do well; he power of the Feds can advance society for the better.  Just depends on what you want.

Is this guy serious? This is the guy who received a flood of money from outside of Wisconsin, was bought and sold many times over by the Koch Brothers and their oil and gas buddies, and put all that ill gotten money to work to buy votes so he could hammer the working people in his own state.

Here is a man who considers a plumber or teacher who belongs to a union a "special interest", but thinks his billionaire buddies and their corporations are entitled to buy elections for politicians like himself. A man who considers undisclosed, unlimited dark money in campaigns to be "free speech", but wants to bar workers from contributing to a union that negotiates for decent working conditions and dignity for them and their co-workers.

Now he pats himself in the back for his "courage"? Clearly he has never walked in the shoes of someone truly courageous - someone who is willing to buck the rich and powerful, and speaks truth to power. Buy yourself a clue, Mr.Walker. you certainly have plenty of dark money to do it with!
What a great idea - these so-called conservatives should be all for this if they really believed in local control rather than socialism for rural communities.

"Explain that the centerpiece in the Republican agenda — returning authority to the states — is the best solution to our nation’s problems."  You mean the problems of Obama's 8 years of unemployment dropping from 10% to 4.6%, the violent crime rate at it's lowest since 1970, a stock market that nearly tripled, median sales prices of existing single-family homes up 23 percent?  Those problems?  Or that in fiscal year 2015, the deficit was $438 billion, a drop of 69 percent from FY 2009? (you can't get rid of the debt until you get rid of deficits, Scott).  Or the problem of no longer being mired in two major wars and wisely not entering another one?  Or maybe it's the problem of the US no longer committing  the war crime of torture?  So many problems for you Rs to "fix."

So, Scotty, how come your neighboring Blue state, Minnesota, is growing faster and creating more jobs than Wisconsin without all the suppression of dissent, shady legislative actions, suppression of investigations into illegal campaign activities and crushing of the unions--just asking

Because he is a senior elected official with an opinion and the NYT has an obligation to report such opinions when they come from people who have been election-tested. It may be a poor opinion and even contrary to right reason, but it is a legitimate opinion piece (which I wholeheartedly disagree with).
